title: Electric flux net flux through Gaussian cube

content.description: A cubic Gaussian surface with one corner located at the origin of a coordinate system has sides of length <math alttext="0.1 meter" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.1</mn><mtext> m</mtext></math> each extending along the <math alttext="positive x" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi></math>, <math alttext="positive y" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi></math>, and <math alttext="positive z" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mi>z</mi></math> axes, as shown. This cube is in a region with a uniform electric field <math alttext="E" overflow="scroll"><mi>E</mi></math> described by the equation <math alttext="E equals, open parenthesis, negative 100 newtons per coulomb, close parenthesis, times i hat, plus, open parenthesis, negative 50 newtons per coulomb, close parenthesis, times j hat, plus, open parenthesis, 200 newtons per coulomb, close parenthesis, times k hat" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mi>E</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mpadded> <mo>−</mo> <mn>100</mn> <mspace width="0.25em"> </mspace> </mpadded> <mtext>N/C</mtext> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mover> <mi>i</mi> <mo>∧</mo> </mover> <mo>+</mo> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mpadded> <mo>−</mo> <mn>50</mn> </mpadded> <mspace width="0.2em"> </mspace> <mtext>N/C</mtext> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mover> <mi>j</mi> <mo>∧</mo> </mover> <mo>+</mo> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mn>200</mn> <mspace width="0.2em"> </mspace> <mtext>N/C</mtext> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mover> <mi>k</mi> <mo>∧</mo> </mover> </mstyle> </math>.
content.question: What is the magnitude of the electric flux through the right (shaded) face of the Gaussian surface?

choices.label: <math alttext="0.5 newton per meter squared coulomb" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>0.5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><msup><mtext>N/(m</mtext><mi>2</mi></msup><mo>·</mo><mtext>C)</mtext></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="1.0 newton per meter squared coulomb" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>1.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>N/</mtext><mrow><msup><mtext>(m</mtext><mi>2</mi></msup><mo>·</mo><mtext>C)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="2.5 newtons per meter squared coulomb" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>2.5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>N/</mtext><mrow><msup><mtext>(m</mtext><mi>2</mi></msup><mo>·</mo><mtext>C)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="1.0 newton per meter squared coulomb" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>1.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>N/</mtext><mrow><msup><mtext>(m</mtext><mi>2</mi></msup><mo>·</mo><mtext>C)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

unit.text: 8: Electric Charges, Fields, and Gauss's Law

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
